awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the conference "The Web of Modularity", to be held at Tulane University on February 22-25, 2024. This conference will be held in conjunction with the annual Clifford Lectures, hosted every year by the Tulane Math Department. In 2024, the Clifford Lectures will be given by Ken Ono. The goal of the conference is to bring together researchers working with modular forms in a variety of contexts, emphasizing the diverse applications of the classical theory of modular forms and bringing together researchers working on different but related problems in the areas of modular forms and number theory. 

In recent years, modular forms of various types have played an important role in diverse and active research areas in mathematics, including Gaussian hypergeometric functions over finite fields, integer partitions, mock modular forms, knot theory, and the modularity of functions arising in differential equations and mathematical physics. By uniting experts who have made significant contributions to these areas, this conference will explore novel perspectives at the forefront of modular forms research.


Conference website: https://sites.google.com/view/clifford-lectures-24/home

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE ADMINISTRATORS OF TULANE EDUCATIONAL FUND

por.por_cntn:
This project provided funding for the conference "The Web of Modularity", which was held February 22-25, 2024. The conference was held at Tulane University in conjunction with the annual Clifford Lectures, which have been hosted every year by the Tulane Math Department since 1984. In 2024, they were delivered by Ken Ono. The conference brought together researchers working with modular forms in a variety of contexts, emphasizing diverse applications of classical modular forms and related real-analytic modular forms in number theory and combinatorics.

This project supported participant costs for the conference. More specifically, supplementing funding from Tulane University for plenary speakers, the funding provided by this project supported travel and lodging for fifteen participants, including seven PhD students, six postdocs, and two tenure-track faculty.  

The conference featured three lectures by Ken Ono (the 2024 Clifford Lectures) and lectures others on various topics in the area of modular forms. The first event was a public lecture held on February 22. The conference then continued through February 25. Eight plenary speakers each gave a fifty minute lecture, eight additional invited speakers gave thirty minute talks, and there were 3 concurrent sessions of 5 ten-minute talks each given by postdocs and graduate students. Each talk was followed by a question and discussion period and either a five minute break or a longer coffee break. There were a total of 69 participants for the conference, including 45 participants from institutions outside Tulane. 

Additional information and photos can be found at the conference webpage https://sites.google.com/view/clifford-lectures-24/home.

 


Last Modified: 12/17/2024
Modified by: Olivia Beckwith
